Posts.Content: dragonfly wrote: My name is Debra, I am a stage IV with mets to bone originally, then to liver.  Right now my liver is so enlarged it is pressing up against other organs.  I did a round of Navelbine to no avail, then started Doxil, 2 weeks out from Doxil, no change yet.  Saw Onc yesterday, wants to look again in 2 more weeks.  She is thinking about Abraxane if my body can process it as the next step. I need to hear from others who have been successfully treated for liver mets, what chemo worked for them, if they had any other treatment.  Was your liver enlarged too? Any information you can share will be helpful.  I live in Mass, and am thinking about going to Boston for a second opinion as I can't take much more of this. Thanks!!!! Debra ~~the girl with the little red corvette since dx'd w/ stage 4 Dx 8/2007, Stage IV, 0/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Calling All Liver Mets-Need Input dragonfly stitchyphish

I have decided to pursue a 2nd opinion at the Dana Farber Cancer ctr in Boston.  I am hearing from all of your responses is that chemo doesn't necessarily work, at least not for the long haul.  And that a targeted therapy may be the best bet.  Will keep this post going, and still invite more input. Debra

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 06:42AM Dragonfly-4 wrote: Thank You all so very much for your words of encouragement.  I have  a doctor's appointment with my regular doctor who is the care doctor here in our town and I am hoping to get some more information from him that I didn't get from the big city ocologist I saw Monday, in regards to all this.   It all has been so overwhelming and living in a small town there just isn't the support here that I need.  I am so thankful for all of you.  I am also meeting this afternoon with a social worker as we have three sons (21, 18 & 14 yrs)  and I need to know how to handle all of this with them, especially my already angry and hormonal 14 year old.  I turn 47 on the 10th and see the Oncologist in Winnipeg,the day before it.  It sure would be nice if she would have a lan by then.  Thanks so much for all your kind words and hugs.  My husband and I have appreciated them more than you will ever know. Dragonfly 9 I mnamed myself that as I love them)  My real name is Janene

Posts.Content: Dragonfly-4 wrote: HI All, I have been reading these pages while anxiously awaiting the results from my bone scan and ct scan.  ct scan was good no spread inthe body.  But bone scan was so upsetting.  Skull mets and also possible in ribs.  The oncologist could give me no idea of what they are going       t o do for treatment for me.  She sent me away for two weeks so she can have a meeting with her colleages.  I am so frightened to say the very least.   I know no one who is in a similar situation who can help me through this.  I was hoping there was someone here that could hold my hand .  They had to do another test to see if I am Her2+ as it went missing in my pathology the oncologist nurse said.   I am estrogen positive but don't know the %.  I had 4 positive node, grade 2 , 3.2 tumour with clear margins.   Any kind words or help would be appreciated. Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 10:51AM Dragonfly-4 wrote: Well I had my meeting with my local Doctor who is also my cancer Doctor ( not my onc). Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 11:44AM Dragonfly-4 wrote: Thank You all for your well wishes and support.  Its great feeling I am not alone.  I caught onto something yesterday and they are now checking through all my pathology reports as my first biopsy done on the tumor prior to surgery said i was er+ , my Onc said I was Er+ but when my local doctor looked at final pathology report and went over it with me extensively on Wednesday it said I was Er-.  So I phoned the Ocn's office and told her that there was a discrepancy somewhere.  Are mistakes like this made often?  Can they now go back and figure out the estrogen status ?  Can they do it with a blood test?  My Ocn is away until mid next week so I am feeling in limbo.  I phoned my regular docotr and he was very upset about it.  I surew hope they get this straightened out so they can get me on the right medicine if needed! Janene

Posts.Title: HER2 + Gals - a Question mthomp2020 mthomp2020

Posts.Content: dragonfly wrote: Back in april I put out a post about how I was chasing down a different diagnosis from mets to bone, such as Paget's disease, and that I went off Femara and Zometa thinking that I didn't have mets to bone.  Just had bloodwork done last week that indicated high tumor markers, so got my answer, and am not chasing down doc specialists anymore.  Went back on Femara and had an IV Zometa today.  Have to say, I've been in a real dark mood since, revising my life insurance policy, and feeling a need to get my "ducks in a row" so to speak.  At the same time, I have an urgency to go do the things that I still want to do with my life, and this is all coming at me at the same time, just flooded with feelings and thoughts.  I know this will settle down in time, but I am also really angry and want to scream and think I should do so at the nearest vacated beach :) I am a single gal and don't feel like I have a ton of support with a fragmented family, and long distance friends, so I feel soooooo alone in this.  That's why I am back on this site ... I need your energy, your encouragement, and yeah, maybe some yuk yuks ... Love yas, Debra  ~~the girl with the little red corvette since dx'd w/ stage 4 Dx 8/2007, Stage IV, 0/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: dragonfly wrote: I am in a quandry, last Aug. '07 I was diagnosed with mets to the bone, no organ involvement, got started on Femara and Zometa by IV, never had a bone biopsy to confirm diagnosis.  Just changed Onc (because the former Onc was a bit of a jerk), new Onc wants to do a surgical bone biopsy to confirm that what is going on in my bones is really related to my original breast cancer diagnosis (2001-stage 1, lumpectomy, rads, no chemo).  I am so surgery phobic its not funny.  Tumor markers have been normal for the past several months.  The type of lesions I have are osteoblastic, versus osteolytic.  (Osteolytic is the typical presentation for breast ca mets to bone)  - osteoblastic means new bone formation, osteolytic is little holes in the bones.  Anyway, had a bone marrow biopsy done last week w/ local anesthesia (not fun, by the way), came back normal - no presence of cancer cells.  I am sooo confused about what to do next.  This doc says it could be Paget's disease, a bone disease.  Radiologists are hospital insist it is breast ca mets to bone ???   Anyone out there who may have similar experience, would you put yourself through surgery when you hate it more than anything to find out one way or another? Any and all insights/opinions welcomed!!! Thanks, Debra ~~the girl with the little red corvette since dx'd w/ stage 4 Dx 8/2007, Stage IV, 0/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Debra

My cancer doctor said something about pamidronate. River, I felt so deflated with the news but with the help of friends and people on this website I am determined to battle hard.  It took a lot to find the fight in myself.  I pray you find it too! Hugs, Dragonfly

All the radiologists at the hospital believe it is bone mets, but my new onc thinks "in his heart of hearts" that its Paget's.  I think its bone mets, and am sick of going through extraneous procedures to confirm it, so, we'll see what happens when I see him this Friday.  I learned from this post that osteoblastic might be resolving osteolytic lesions ... that gave me a ton of hope - thanks to whoever shared that info .. Posts.Title: Is it Bone Mets or Something Else? dragonfly dragonfly

Posts.Content: dragonfly wrote: I am one year out of being diagnosed with Stage IV mets to the bone and have started Femara and Zometa IV.  My Onc has me on 2.5 of Femara daily, and 3mg of Zometa IV every other month.  The mets are stable at this time, and I am being told that I am in partial remission, which is great news.  I would like to have a scan done every 6 months to closely watch, but Onc says only if I have symptoms and complaints which may indicate more mets.  He also says my blood counts would be an indicator of more mets, which have been in the normal range for a few months now.  At visit with Onc today learned that Zometa will be stopped and replaced with Fosamax per oral, and that my next follow up (including bloodwork) would be in 6 months.  He did not recommend another PetScan until 1 year from last scan which was in May, of '08.  I need to check in with others with same dx. to see if this treatment plan is on track, or if I should be more closely monitored.  I would love to think that I am home free, but when one is dx'd with stage 4 the hypervigilance to monitor doesn't stop in my opinion.  Please share your thoughts and current treatment plans with same dx - I really need some input from others.  Thanks,   Debra ~~the girl with the little red corvette since being dx'd with stage 4!!!~~ ~~the girl with the little red corvette since dx'd w/ stage 4 Dx 8/2007, Stage IV, 0/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
